title: Thursday, 13th December 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Good morning. Hello. Hi there. Welcome.

BE11:05am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

Manxish Morning everyone
MassimoJ Morning
Soundbuy Oi
Curious Morning. Slow news day.G4S?
BE11:05am

So .......... last night was the FT staff Christmas party.

Blank canvas Good morning from Madrid
11:05 am
BE11:06am

I had an excellent evening: I didn't go.

VV75 morning
Kiwi-juice morning. A comment on GAM please. This is a death spiral.
Shrink Evening.
Shrink Sensible decision BE.
BE11:06am

Those that did report outbreaks of karaoke.

Soundbuy There's a cream for that........
BE11:07am

Video, I'm sure, will surface, as video inevitably does. For those that can't quite remember the detail of last night, it's probably best to keep one eye on Mark Di Stefano's twitter.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Anyway. Let's crack on with the day's events.

undefined
BE11:09am

FTSE's flattish, £'s flattish, oil's flattish, gold's flattish ......

VV75 Mike Ashley was not very happy with november..

Kiwi-juice also some gray on PZC please. Africa's is the future but not in the Stockmarket

FATDAZ Morning all
GBKrona Jambo

So let's head straight into corporate. G4S got the first mention so ........

Lemmy Jambo bwana
G4S PLC (GFS:LSE): Last: 199.75, up 16.4 (+8.94%), High: 202.40, Low: 194.20, Volume: 2.89m
11:10 am

(@Excel: Brent's down 0.5%. That's not a move, it's a rounding error.)

BE11:11am

Cash transportation's going to be split out or sold.

BE11:11am

Probably the former, if there are buyers, and there are likely to be any number of interested parties.

Grouchmonkey Morning
11:12 am
BE11:12am

Loomis, Prosegur, assorted PE firms ......

casapinos Is cash obsolescent?
BE11:13am

Apax Partners and PAI being the most obvious ones.

cheeckychappy @casapinos - is obsolescent an actual word?
BE11:13am

Also remember that Charterhouse bid £1.55bn for G4S Cash Solutions back in 2013.

Soundbuy yep, becoming obsolete.
casapinos @cheecky think so "on the way to being obsolete"
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Though the business was a quite different shape back then. Multiple disposals since.

Grouchmonkey @casapinos yes. https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-46507529

Anyway, in terms of valuation, it's a bit tricky.

Noname it's definitely a word but its dying out a bit...
Kiwi-juice There is this Spruce Point Capital Management short seller, promising a report on a multi-billion dollar short idea this afternoon (https://www.sprucepointcap.com) that sounds like GE, with bullet points like someone recently appointed is a stock promoter, that there are some fraudulent actions... Promises a lot of action
Soundbuy Ho ho..........
BE11:15am

Cash Sols was 17% of G4S's 2017 sales and 28% of EBITA pre central costs ..... but that includes Cash360, and it's not clear whether management want to hold onto that.

cracklenpop Grey on Webvan 2.0 pls.
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Cash360 alone was 5-6% of 2017 group EBITA

BE11:16am

But back to the top. Here's Stifel saying it's good news because G4S has been a dog.

BE11:16am

[W]e believe shareholder value can be created from this. The two businesses have a very distinct proposition with few synergies from having them under the same roof. A separation would we believe allow better management focus and create two global leaders in their own right. It is clear that four years into its turnaround, investors have been losing patience with G4S. Frustratingly, the good progress in Cash Solutions was being obfuscated by legacy issues as well as poor communication along the way. A separation of the two businesses would lead to a clearer investment proposition and reinvigorate the equity story, in our view.

Ethelred Rumours about G4S selling the cash division recur regularly
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Cash use will die out with the Brexit voters.
rw42 Cash use will continue here as a backup for as long as banks outsource IT to the lowest bidder.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

(@Ethelred: it's on the tape. I'm not sure we can still call it a rumour.)

casapinos !st LT I've got some sacks for carrying bitcoin I could sell you
BE11:18am

Kepler argues the same.

Fh Any news on Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank?
BE11:18am

The announcement of a review of spin off options for Cash solutions is great news as it should highlight: 1) the bargain nature of G4S share price; 2) the 50% discount to an SOP using peers’ multiples; and 3) the prospects for a significant acceleration of earnings momentum in 2019-20E. The panic that followed the weaker-than-expected Q3 trading statement was indeed bound to force a reaction by management, bearing in mind that the G4S share price is not being rewarded for its industryleading technology solutions nor for the soon-to-be-seen payback of its five-year-long restructuring efforts.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The severity of the share price reaction to a very small delay in the confirmed recovery scenario highlighted the nervousness of the market with regards to business services with a strong UK exposure (est. 20% of group EBIT depending on allocation of central costs) amidst Brexit talks and pushed the stock to bargain territory. G4S trades on c. 7x EBITDA on our forecasts. This compares with 8.4x for Prosegur Cash and 10.5x for Securitas and 6.5x for Loomis, while Brinks and Wendel paid 12x EBITDA for comparable assets recently. The group is 75% Securitas and 25% Loomis, meaning 9.7x is more appropriate, hence our TP of 300p.

BE11:20am

The not irrelevant follow-up question here is, how much will shareholders actually see of any disposal proceeds?

BE11:20am

And the answer may well be, "less than they might expect".

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @casapinos - Now what would I want with Bitcoin? It isn't even a currency. It is a gamble for idiots and a ponzi scheme past its zenith.
Excel Developer #ECB #Macro #QE Dragi to announce end of QE program today. also updated growth forecasts.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Because G4S is carrying 3.1x net debt including the pension deficit.

BE11:21am

Here's Citi.

BE11:21am

Given G4S’ significant tax losses, we expect any
disposal gains to be offset by tax carryforwards. In terms of pensions, however, G4S has pledged a share of any “material” disposal proceeds to the UK pension scheme, in the same proportion as the pension deficit (2017 UK pension deficit: £250m) bears to overall group indebtedness (2017 Net debt: £1487m). We believe this means that G4S will pay 15-20% of any material proceeds into its UK pension scheme, but we note that its triennial review should probably complete next year, which may affect this calculation.

11:21 am
undefined
BE11:21am

Okay, so Deutcherz Bank

BE11:22am

Bloomberg got itchy yesterday and hit post on the story everyone's been dancing around for months.

casapinos !st Lt agreed!
11:22 am
BE11:23am

(Bloomberg) -- The German government is intensifying
efforts to help fix Deutsche Bank AG, with officials studying
ways to make it easier to merge with Commerzbank AG, people
familiar with the matter said.
The high-level discussions -- which have included Finance
Minister Olaf Scholz and Deutsche Bank Chief Executive Officer
Christian Sewing-- are looking at concrete ways the government
can assist in a potential combination of the country’s two-
largest lenders, said the people, asking not to be identified
discussing the private deliberations. The talks include
potentially changing existing laws to make the steps necessary
for a merger less costly, they said.
Nonetheless, the talks about a merger are in an exploratory
phase and other possibilities such as seeking fresh investment
from existing or new shareholders are also still being
considered, one person said.

BE11:24am

They could use that in journalism schools as a lesson in how to deploy as many parachutes as possible.

BornCynic Morning - if possible PZ Cussons please.
casapinos @BE the two drunks theory?
BE11:26am

And I should note, the gist from people familiar with things in response to the Bloomberg story yesterday was to calm down. No great urgency, apparently.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Though that's what you'd expect people talking about a shotgun marriage of a nation's two biggest lenders to day, I guess.

cracklenpop @BE looks like a state-aided bail-out but of course the Germans won't call it that. .
BornCynic Such as what is "optimising price points and pack sizes across the keybrands in the portfolio"
Viking1 Do not forget DB is involved in Danske Bank incident
BE11:27am

No one wants to get the blame for queues outside the door. No one wants to do a Peston.

Excel Developer @BE: cripes, Euro atrea policymakers are supposed to be stopping doom loop sovereign and national banks. It would be best if consolidation took place across borders.
BE11:28am

Have some Metzler for the scenario analysis.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

If such a combination was to take place, we would expect a dreadful cut of the workforce. We would estimate the restructuring costs at approx. EUR 3.5-3.8 bn (including items like IT, office space, marketing, etc.). In our view, it would take many years until the new entity was realigned.

Viking1 DWS disposal
nichoman what's wrong with deutsche ? concern it doesn't have enough capital?
BE11:28am

"a dreadful cut of the workforce" is a lovely phrase, which I suspect is via Google Translate.

BE11:29am

Based on our estimate of 41,500 full time employees (FTEs) at Deutsche Bank's German operations and 31,000 at Commerzbank (also Germany only) as of 09/18, we would expect that in the long run (i.e. 5-8 years time) roughly 22,000 FTE's might be cut in such a scenario. We would estimate approx. EUR 2.5-2.8 bn longer-term cost savings p.a. (staff, other costs) which appears large compared to our combined EBT estimate of EUR 4.4 bn for both groups in 2019e. However, we would see some revenues at risk (some business clients might seek diversified bank relationships).

Excel Developer @nichoman: a flat yield curve doesn't help, kills net interest margin.
Joesph H Zoap. PURP?
tadam @be is this because you are not attending? TRUMP CANCELS WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS PARTY FOR PRESS
rw42 I'm sure they'll learn well from the lloyds failed backend migration too!
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Any update on the probability scenarios for Brexit after yesterday's sorry circus?
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Looking beyond the government-sanctioned jobs bonfire that this entails, we should highlight that Commerzbank's at a price of just 0.3 times 2018 book value.

BE11:31am

Deutsche buying Commerzbank would therefore trigger a write-up of negative goodwill.

nichoman @1stLt - its gone soft

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Dunno for sure, but I think the people familiar with things who are saying nothing imminent are probably telling the truth here.

Peel Hunt's shop broker here ......

Irish HF guy Plato the Cook, Sparkasse, but it is locally owned. Targo also have a presence and N26 are online but not for business
BE11:39am

Purplebricks has posted a decent set of results despite the mixed trading backdrop in its key end markets. The UK has significantly outperformed the wider market, and profits have risen smartly. The focus in the US will now be on developing the proposition in the seven states in which it is operating, while the second half of the year will be a key test for the new Australian proposition and management team after a tricky H1. Overall, we have trimmed our revenue expectations by 5% for FY19 and by 14% for FY20 and FY21. We continue to forecast a group profit bin FY21. Target price is reduced to 320p and Buy maintained.

BE11:39am

The shares have fallen by 64% in YTD, and on
revised forecasts trade on a FY21 EV/Sales of 1.2x and EV/EBITDA of 23x. We have cut out target price to 320p (from 440p) and retain our Buy recommendation.

Flaneur The solution to 'Too big to fail' - as predicted here many moons ago - seems to be to make them even bigger...

BE11:40am

Strong bottom line UK performance shows the business model. Australia issues likely to take another 6 months to return to growth and the US we look towards 2H18 given the early stage of a number of markets and the anticipated marketing launch in the new year. Overall result is in line with our expectations and should be seen as favourable given the recent negativity, particularly around UK.

Today’s numbers will cause downgrades in consensus expectations but we flag that Purplebricks is at the tipping point in terms of profitability and small downgrades in absolute numbers result in a large percentage change.

BornCynic Arconic seems to have hired some lawyers who have sold their soul..........."Grenfell cladding firm: 'fire could have been put out with simple extinguisher' "
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Ultra Electronics, as mentioned by @Urgeview, is a very very good Barclays note.

BE11:43am

The company has a pretty dull trading update out today, coincidentally. But it's Barclays putting together the short case that's doing the damage.

Ultra Electronics Holdings PLC (ULE:LSE): Last: 1,287, down 94 (-6.81%), High: 1,346, Low: 1,230, Volume: 639.94k
Joesph H Zoap. "We have cut out target price to 320p (from 440p) and retain our Buy recommendation."SP currently 133p, a fabulous bargain that will make us all as rich as Croesus.
11:45 am
BE11:45am

The upshot is that Ultra's cashflow is weirdly bad, net receivables have been growing for several years at a multiple of operating profits, all the acquisitions look to have been rubbish, and management's definition of "underlying" needs some explanation.

BE11:46am

I summarise in full in the daily Stocks to Watch thing, which seems to be stuck in a sub queue right now, so I'll cut and paste it here for convenience.

BE11:47am

Barclays cut Ultra Electronics Holdings to “underweight” from “equal weight” with a £11.20 target price. The downgrade overshadowed a trading update from the defence technology group confirming that performance was in line with expectations.

Analysis of Ultra’s accounts over the past five years showed underlying profits included low-quality items while excluding significant costs, said Barclays. Its team also questioned Ultra’s acquisition record, highlighting regular impairment losses and a lack of evidence that earn-out targets were ever met.

Underlying operating profit and cash flow have been consistently higher than operating profit under GAAP accounting standards, said the broker, which criticised Ultra’s historic treatment of currency effects, dividends from associates and non-cash gains from provision releases. Barclays also criticised the group’s “general lack of clarity” regarding acquisition and disposal-related payments, which it said were not included in underlying metrics and not reference elsewhere in financial statements.

Added to that, Barclays called Ultra’s cash conversion “concerning” at just 78 per cent on average between 2013 and 2017. Increasing working capital demands have meant that net receivables grew six times faster than operating profits over the period, it said. But new IFRS 15 accounting rules defer the company’s revenue recognition, which combined with a depleted reserve of provisions and reduced acquisition activity means Ultra will have to rebase its sector-leading profit margins, said the broker.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

That's what you'll get to read later, over here, eventually: https://www.ft.com/stocks-to-watch

Upaswellasdown think Zugzwang means that the obligation to go next puts you at a disadvantange. Think you mean f***tangle.
Excel Developer @BE: You did Deutsche at 11:23.
11:53 am
BE11:53am

In line with expectations, Prime Minister May won last night's Conservative Party confidence vote by a margin of 200 to 117. The loss of more than a third of the parliamentary party underscores deep divisions over the Prime Minister's leadership and handling of Brexit, but in practical terms it means she is safe from another vote for twelve months. May has now flown to Brussels to attend the EU Council.

BE11:53am

There was no clear direction from the Prime Minister about her Brexit strategy in her statement last night, although reports have suggested the UK government is now seeking legally binding commitments from the EU27 over the Temporary Customs Arrangement in the Withdrawal Agreement.

BE11:54am

In our view, the prospect of substantively changing the existing Withdrawal Agreement is limited, other than by replacing a whole UK backstop with a Northern Ireland specific one. As Prime Minister May has ruled out any Brexit deal that does not gain the support of the DUP, the latter seems unlikely. In summary, should the UK stance continue to center on iterations of the current agreement, it is unlikely to pass a parliamentary vote late this year or, more likely, in January. The UK government has committed to a vote by January 21st.

Markkus Prosecco producers will come through for the UK, where German car makes failed to!
red zugzwang is what could describe the eu. they would prefer to do nothing now, but prob need to offer olive branch to help may back in uk
11:54 am
BE11:54am

In our last piece, we argued that should Prime Minister May survive the confidence vote, we would view the outlook as bullish for Brexit negotiations.
However, this rests on the assumption that May will now pivot towards a cross party approach to Brexit, in particular softening the stance on the future relationship to gain Labour Party support. Our baseline is that the Prime Minister seeks changes to the language in the Political Declaration on the Future Relationship, either by making explicit a commitment to permanent customs union with the EU27, or a Norway-plus future relationship. This should command sufficient support in parliament for ratification. This thesis will now be tested.

Tom Dalgleish Trademarked already, Noname
BE11:54am

The alternative is that Prime Minister May runs down the clock and returns to parliament with simply a further iteration of the current agreement. In these circumstances, the deal is unlikely to pass. Either parliament will have to coordinate over giving instructions to the government to seek a softer Brexit deal via amendments to the vote, or the government will fall in a motion of confidence and new elections will take place. A crash Brexit may still be avoided, but the damage to the economy in the interim will be considerable, as no deal planning from both the private and public sector accelerates. We think the likelihood of a second referendum is low. By mid-January, there will be insufficient time to hold one without an extension of Article 50 beyond the European Parliamentary Elections in May. We doubt the EU27 would agree to extend Article 50 beyond this point.

Irish HF guy How about GAM, what a mess!
Excel Developer ah, that's Deutsche bank analysis of Brexit ( embarrased face)

Brutto GAM, and other asset managers also...
BE11:56am

That's Deutsche economist Oliver Harvey, whose name always sets off an earworm along the lines of "Oliver Harvey is here to stay, Oliver Harvey are on their way."

red thats a good point, may elections in eu are a point by which path must be clear, good bad or ugly.
BornCynic You could sum all this up better "We are all going to be poorer - we just don't know by how much yet".
11:56 am
BE11:57am

Also, Merrill in synopsis.

BE11:57am

Our Brexit base case remains a deal that allows the UK to Brexit smoothly to transition. But most scenarios involve delay. Given the balance of risks, we push back our BoE rate hike call to November 2019 from May 2019. Rates: long end vol a wake up call to DMO. GBP: beholden to Brexit headlines but should rally in 2019.

red @BornCynicnot quite the case, there are winners and losers.
Irish HF guy @Brutto, working in the industry, Shareholders in asset management entities are a poor third relation to the Portfolio managers and Bond Holders. Other than being taken out, returns for shareholders have not been great and there is a lot of names of failed promises and disappointing returns
BE11:57am

And Citi.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

‘No deal’ perhaps a bit more likely – If the deal fails, May or a potential successor if she steps down, could switch to pursuing no deal preparations. Parliament, which has already increasingly asserted its power in this process, may try and stop this by denying government necessary funds or rejecting legislation or by trying to force the government to change tack with amendments or by forcing new elections with a confidence vote. May’s victory, however close, highlights the weakness of the anti-EU European Research Group of Tory in Parliament. It would probably take another referendum with a vote for 'no deal' for this outcome, or an election that delivers a huge swing towards 'no deal'.

Flaneur Great Brexit/confidence vote analogy on BBC last night.Movie car chase, one car goes off road, through cardboard boxes, mud and a barn. Comes out the other side with straw and chickens flying everywhere only to rejoin the chase in the same position....
Brutto @irish HF guy. tell me about it - I'm long DWS...
BE11:58am

‘No Brexit’ also a bit more likely – With May’s deal less likely to pass, chances are rising that Brexit will be postponed with an Article 50 TEU extension or even revocation to win time. That could be for a second referendum to reverse Brexit or for ‘no deal’ preparations, for example.

Upaswellasdown Please can you ask Rob Smith to keep digging on GAM / Greensill / Liberty?

red you can see them forwarding a motion to revoke art 50 in event of no deal

BE12:00pm

BE12:03pm

GAMH Investment Management AuM is now CHF 60.8bn (Nov 2018). Assuming ~55bp fee margin, then this can generate CHF334m revenue. Adding in ca. CHF 46m for Private Label, we estimate total run-rate revenue at around CHF 380m. For 2018E, we estimate CHF 125m PBT will be achieved on CHF 500m revenue: i.e. our current run-rate estimate is a CHF 120m revenue shortfall from 2018E levels, even if GAMH sees no further AUM decline.

Irish HF guy And this was with Archie Busson on board. Nothing they could do with terminal decline of FOF business and poor brand name

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

“More than CHF 40m” cost savings will struggle to offset CHF 125m fall in run-rate revenue (even before we factor in market volatility and the risk of further outflows). Our forecast of “materially lower” PBT in 2019E is CHF 45m: a 64% fall YoY and enough to support only CHF 0.22 EPS.

Here's RBC.

BE12:15pm

Sports Direct has reported softer than expected H1 results today with revenue 1% below our forecast and EBITDA (including House of Fraser) of
£149mn, 5% below our forecast of £157mn. Underlying PBT was £64.4mn, 7% below our forecast of £69.5mn. Net debt of £505mn is broadly in line with
our forecast. These results reinforce our view that SPD is finding it challenging to drive growth outside of its core UK sportswear business and that the
recent House of Fraser acquisition will be a material drag on earnings for the group.
SPD has reiterated its guidance for EBITDA for the core business to be up 5-15% yoy, however we expect the overall result to be diluted by the House
of Fraser acquisition which is heavily loss-making.

Irish HF guy TUI results show a large gap to T Cook. Was looking at TUI, they own 50% of RIU chain and seem somewhat undervalued on a sum of the parts basis. Maybe tomorrow BE can look again at TUI
12:15 pm
BE12:16pm

House of Fraser a big drag. House of Fraser reported an EBITDA loss of £32mn for the period below our £-20mn estimate, partly as HoF lost online sales
for almost two months as systems and processes were reset and it reset its logistics arrangements. Also store closure costs look higher than we
expected. We continue to believe department stores such as House of Fraser will face challenges owing to a loss of range advantage to online players
and high fixed costs when high street footfall is under pressure.

BE12:16pm

Sports Direct has a strong position in UK sports retailing and asset backing from strategic stakes in other retailers, but we think it will be challenging to
execute on its strategy to upgrade its brand and store portfolio in the UK.
Department stores such as House of Fraser continue to face structural pressures and SPD faces opex pressure from higher labour costs. Finally we
expect ROCE to come under further pressure as capital intensity rises as a result of SPD's acquisitions of freeholds and as it moves more into premium
fashion.
Valuation is c.14x CY19 P/E which we regard as full given SPD’s falling ROCE and challenging EPS outlook.

BE12:19pm

H1 2018 was clearly a difficult period for the company with a tough market (notably NHS, but also a slowdown in self-pay) further impacted by operational missteps. From here, UK political focus remains elsewhere, which in our view means NHS decisions likely remain paralysed. Furthermore, we see Brexit impacting consumer confidence and potentially driving some reticence in the self-pay market. Overall, we find it difficult to construct a positive near-term outlook, other than the shares are cheap (which is true if the company can turn recent earnings momentum). We believe investors will need to see evidence that a bottom has been reached (we see some further near-term downgrades given consensus remains at the top of the guidance range). Following our estimate revisions, our PT falls to Dec-19 146p (from 256p).
